greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: If n = Product (p_j^k_j) then a(n) = Sum (a(n/p_j^k_j)), with a(1) = 1.
comment: Number of ordered prime factorizations of radical of n.

Number of permutations of the prime indices of n (counting multiplicity) avoiding the patterns (1,2,1) and (2,1,2). These are permutations with all equal parts contiguous. Depends only on sorted prime signature (A118914). - _Gus Wiseman_, Jun 27 2020
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Gus Wiseman, Sequences counting and ranking compositions by the patterns they match or avoid.
example: The a(n) permutations of prime indices for n = 2, 12, 60:
mathematica: a[1] = 1; a[n_] := a[n] = Sum[If[GCD[n/d, d] == 1 && d < n, Boole[PrimePowerQ[n/d]] a[d], 0], {d, Divisors[n]}]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 100}]
xref: Permutations of prime indices are A008480.
Unsorted prime signature is A124010. Sorted prime signature is A118914.
(1,2,1)-avoiding permutations of prime indices are A335449.
(2,1,2)-avoiding permutations of prime indices are A335450.
(1,2,1) or (2,1,2)-matching permutations of prime indices are A335460.
(1,2,1) and (2,1,2)-matching permutations of prime indices are A335462.
results.author: _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Mar 11 2020
